facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 768 of 1963 filed by special leave from Allahabad High Court judgment dated May 6, 1963 in F.A.F.O. No. 116 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLEATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 768 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 6, 1963, of the Allahabad High Court in F.A.F.O. No. 116 of 1959.

facts.text: Appellant is defendant in Suit 134 of 1956 before Second Civil Judge, Kanpur.

anchor.surface_text: The ex parte decree that was passed against the defendant-who will hereafter be referred to as the appellant-and which he sought to be set aside in the proceedings which are the subject of the present appeal, was in Suit 134 of 1956 on the file of the Court of Second Civil Judge, Kanpur.

facts.text: Phula Kuer filed Small Cause Suit 1023 of 1951 against appellant for Rs. 750 as partnership profits at Rs. 150 per month.

anchor.surface_text: The first of them was a Small Cause suit by one Phula Kuer who sought to recover from the appellant Rs. 750 on the basis that she and the appel- lant were partners and by an arrangement between them he agreed to pay her Rs. 150 per month for her share of the profits which he had failed to pay.

facts.text: Appellant filed Suit No. 20 of 1953 against Phula Kuer for fixing fair rent of premises owned by her.

anchor.surface_text: While this suit was pending, the appellant in his turn filed suit No. 20 of 1953 against Phula Kuer for fixing the fair rent of the premises in which he was carrying on the business, which Phula Kuer alleged was a partnership business, it being companymon ground that Phula Kuer was the owner thereof.

facts.text: Phula Kuer died on July 13, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: While these two suits were pending Phula Kuer died on July 13, 1953 and thereafter one Rup Chand Jain filed suit 134 of 1956 already referred to,

facts.text: Rup Chand Jain filed Suit 134 of 1956 on May 19, 1956 as next reversioner of Phula Kuer claiming Rs. 4200 profits and rent/eviction.

anchor.surface_text: Suit 134 of 1956 which was filed on May 19, 1956 repeated the allegation that Phula Kuer had entered into the partnership with the appellant under which she was entitled to get for her share Rs. 150 per month. This share of profits, it was alleged, had been paid to her up to October 14, 1950

facts.text: Rup Chand Jain died pending appeal in High Court, represented by heirs.

anchor.surface_text: and thereafter one Rup Chand Jain filed suit 134 of 1956 already referred to, Rup Chand Jain died pending the appeal in the High Court and is number represented by his heirs who have been brought on record.

facts.text: Three suits transferred to Second Civil Judge, Kanpur on August 4, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the companytentions of the parties in the three suits, all of them were transferred by the District Judge, to the companyrt of the Second Civil Judge, Kanpur on August 4, 1956,

facts.text: Suits 20/1953 and 134/1956 consolidated for joint hearing on August 23, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: and on August 23, 1956 the Civil Judge passed an order directing that the suits 20 of 1953 and 134 of 1956 be companysolidated for joint hearing, the evidence led in Suit 134 of 1956 being treated as evidence in the other suit as well.

facts.text: Appellant filed written statement in Suit 134/1956 on October 10, 1956 denying partnership and claiming tenancy.

anchor.surface_text: On October 10, 1956 the appellant filed his written statement to Suit 134 of 1956 in which he put forward the case which he had already been asserting viz.,  1  absence of any partnership relationship between himself and Phula Kuer, and  2  that he was in possession as a tenant

facts.text: Joint application by parties on May 24, 1958 for two months to settle, refused by court.

anchor.surface_text: finally, on May 24 1958 a joint application was made by the plaintiff and the appellant that two months time may be granted to them to arrive at a settlement and that the trial which was fixed for May 28, 1958 may be adjourned for that purpose.

facts.text: Trial adjourned from May 28 to May 29, 1958 with order: if no compromise, final hearing.

anchor.surface_text: On the 28th there was again another application for adjournment and the companyrt adjourned the trial by one day and fixed it for May 29, 1958, the order stating If numbercompromise is filed the case would be taken up for final hearing.

facts.text: On May 29, 1958, appellant absent, counsel no instructions, court proceeded ex parte in Suit 134/1956, examined witness, judgment reserved.

anchor.surface_text: On 29th the plaintiff was present but the appellant was absent and the latters companynsel who was present reported that they had numberinstructions to companyduct the case. Thereupon the companyrt passed an order in Suit 134 of 1956 in these terms The plaintiff is present. Defendant is absent.

facts.text: Suit 20/1953 dismissed for plaintiff's absence on May 29, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: In the suit for the fixation of rent which was taken up for trial on the same date the order of the companyrt ran Plaintiff is absent. Defendant with his Counsel is present. Counsel for the plaintiff has numberinstructions. Suit is dismissed as per orders passed separately.

facts.text: Suit 1023/1951 decreed ex parte on May 29, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: It is only necessary to add that the third suit--1023 of 1951-was on the same day also decreed ex parte.

facts.text: Appellant filed applications on May 31, 1958 to set aside ex parte orders citing heat-stroke illness.

anchor.surface_text: On May 31, 1958 the appellant filed three applications in the three suits for setting aside the ex parte orders passed against him. The application in Suit 134 of 1956 was treated as the primary one and in support of it an affidavit was filed in which the appellant stated that after the talks for companypromise

facts.text: Plaintiff filed counter-affidavit disputing appellant's illness claim.

anchor.surface_text: Notices were issued on these applications and the plaintiff filed a companynter-affidavit in which he disputed the truth of the statement regarding the appellants illness and prayed that the applications may be dismissed.

facts.text: Civil Judge on August 23, 1958 held appellant's illness story false, refused set aside for Suit 20/1953, fixed judgment delivery for others on Aug 25.

anchor.surface_text: These three applications were disposed of by a companymon judgment of the Civil Judge on August 23, 1958 and the learned Civil Judge held that the story of the illness of the appellant which had been put forward as affording sufficient reason for number being present in companyrt on May 29, 1958 was false.

facts.text: Appellant filed revision in Allahabad High Court against order in Suit 134/1956, dismissed on September 4, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereupon moved the High Court of Allahabad in revision against the order passed against the refusal of his application in suit 134 of 1956 alone and apparently obtained a stay of delivery of the judgment. This application was disposed of by the High Court on September 4, 1958

facts.text: Appellant applied again post HC order, dismissed by Civil Judge on September 25, 1958; ex parte judgment delivered that day.

anchor.surface_text: Within 4 days of this order of the High Court ... On the same day-September 25, 1958-the judgment which had already been prepared was delivered. The judgment read Both the suits are decreed with companyts ex parte with interest at 6 etc.

facts.text: Appellant filed application under O. IX r.13 to set aside ex parte decree in Suit 134/1956.

anchor.surface_text: To set aside this ex parte decree thus passed against him on September 25, 1958 the defendant filed an application under IX, r. 13. Obviously, the factual ground upon which the relief was sought, viz., that there was reasonable or sufficient cause for the appellants absence from Court on May 29, 1958

facts.text: Civil Judge dismissed O.IX r.13 application on res judicata grounds.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Civil Judge upheld the first preliminary ground of objection and dismissed the application.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court dismissed appeal on May 6, 1963 on res judicata.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant there-upon filed an appeal to the High Court and the learned Judges likewise held that any inquiry into the question whether the appellant had sufficient cause for numberappearance on May 29, 1958 was barred by res judicata

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal, remanded O.IX r.13 application for merits as prior orders not res judicata and O.IX r.7 inapplicable.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is allowed and the application filed by the appellant under O. IX, r. 13 for setting aside the ex parte decree passed in suit 134 of 1956 is remanded to the trial Judge for disposal on the merits in accordance with law.
the present appeal has been brought by special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution.
resjudicata.

issues.text: If an application is made under O. IX, r. 7 and the Court considers that there is no good cause for the previous non-appearance and proceeds further with the suit and ultimately it results in an ex parte decree, can the Court in dealing with the application to set aside the ex parte decree under O. IX, r. 13 reconsider the question as to whether the defendant had a sufficient cause for non-appearance on the day in regard to which the application under O. IX, r. 7 had been filed?

anchor.surface_text: The courts below have approached this question in this form. Order IX, r. 7 reads Where the Court has adjourned the hearing of the suit ex parte, and the defendant, at or before such hearing, appears and assigns good cause for his previous non-appearance, he may, upon such terms as the Court directs as to costs, or otherwise, be heard in answer to the suit as if he had appeared on the day fixed for his appearance. IX, r. 13 and was a bar to the re-inquiry of the same question on the merits?

holdings.text: A decision or direction in an interlocutory proceeding under O. IX, r. 7 does not operate as res judicata to bar the hearing on merits of an application under O. IX, r. 13.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we consider that a decision or direction in an interlocutory proceeding of the type provided for by O. IX, r. 7, is not of the kind which can operate as resjudicata so as to bar the hearing on the merits of an application under O. IX, r. 13. The latter is a specific statutory remedy

holdings.reasoning_summary: O. IX r.7 orders are summary, interlocutory without appeal or finality unlike r.13; policy of Code favors merits hearing; cites Sangram Singh, Madras HC cases rejecting similar res judicata plea.

holdings.text: O. IX r.7 inapplicable where hearing fully completed and judgment reserved; no adjournment of hearing, only of pronouncement.

anchor.surface_text: If, therefore, the hearing was completed and the suit was not adjourned for hearing, O. IX, r.7 could have no application and the matter would stand at the stage of O. IX, r.6 to be followed up by the passing of an ex parte decree making r. 13 the only provision

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual construction of r.7 requires adjournment of hearing ex parte; post-hearing reservation is for pronouncement per O.XX r.1, not hearing; Civil Judge noted only judgment hearing left.

holdings.text: No inherent jurisdiction under s.151 CPC to entertain post-hearing application to set aside ex parte order, as O.IX exhausts contingencies for defendant non-appearance.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Specific O.IX provisions cover all scenarios of defendant absence; inherent power cannot override exhaustive statutory scheme; no gap post-hearing completion before decree.

holdings.text: Finding under O.IX r.9 rejecting restoration in suit 20/1953 does not res judicata O.IX r.13 in suit 134/1956 despite consolidation.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Independent suits despite joint trial/evidence sharing; r.9 concerns plaintiff's default in suit 20 vs defendant's in 134; relief suit-specific, not eadem quaestio.

holdings.text: Ex parte decree in suit 134/1956 not a merits decree under O.XVII r.3 but true ex parte under O.IX.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Adjournment joint for compromise, not solely defendant's instance; all records treat as ex parte; O.XVII r.3 requires time granted to defaulting party for evidence etc.

holdings.text: No material difference between 'good cause' in O.IX r.7 and 'sufficient cause' in O.IX r.13.

anchor.surface_text: we might observe that we do not see any material difference between the facts to be established for satisfying the two tests of good cause and sufficient cause. We are unable to conceive of a good cause which is not sufficient as affording an explanation for non-appearance, nor conversely of a sufficient cause which is not a good one

holdings.reasoning_summary: Terms equivalent; if difference, good cause lighter burden, prior rejection bars stricter test; not seriously pressed.
